history.content:
61B with Hug is similar to 61A. Hug doesn't give that many As, it's Hilfinger who does that. But they're also similar in other ways too. Namely, Hug goes light on projects and makes tricky exams, which is also what 61A likes to do. Hug's version of 61B is definitely similar in workload to 61A, both in terms of the time commitment for projects and the amount of time you should be dedicating to studying for exams.

However, I'm gonna point out a few problems with your schedule. Your first and second semesters are not comparable in terms of difficulty. Math 113 is much harder than 54 and Data 100+Stat 140 is definitely much harder than Data 8+CS 70. Additionally, you shouldn't be taking Stat 140 since it overlaps significantly with 70. The recommended probability class for those who took 70 is EE 126. Data 100 is also of limited usefulness to a CS major, since I'm assuming that you're probably gonna take the full machine learning sequence of classes eventually.

If I were you, I would do CS 61B, Math 113, EE 16B, and a breadth next semester. That will work out to be about as difficult as your current semester and most importantly, 16B will help you get the matrix decomposition practice you need to tackle important classes like EE 127.

-------------------------------------------------------------------

I wouldn't recommend taking EE16B next semester if Jerry Pan already has other courses in mind. Data 100 isn't a bad choice and the overall work load is lighter than 16B. I have friends with negative experience in 16B this semester because online labs doesn't work at all. Since you're a freshman, you have plenty of opportunity to take 16B in the future and hopefully in-person.

Math 113 is much harder than 54 and Data 100+Stat 140 is definitely much harder than Data 8+CS 70. Additionally, you shouldn't be taking Stat 140 since it overlaps significantly with 70. The recommended probability class for those who took 70 is EE 126. Data 100 is also of limited usefulness to a CS major, since I'm assuming that you're probably gonna take the full machine learning sequence of classes eventually.

If I were you, I would do CS 61B, Math 113, EE 16B, and a breadth next semester. That will work out to be about as difficult as your current semester and most importantly, 16B will help you get the matrix decomposition practice you need to tackle important classes like EE 127.

children.subject:
3. I plan to take DATA 100 to be more prepared for Kaggle DS competitions. Why DATA 100 has a larger workload than DATA 8? 

Thanks for answering! Really appreciated!

Stat 140 has a computational component that makes it relatively high workload.

EE 126 isn't designed with Stat 140 as a prerequisite. CS 70 + EE 126 is supposed to be roughly equivalent to Stat 140+Stat 150, but the precise topics they cover are different and the way the classes split the material is different. Don't mix and match the two sequences. If you want to be a stats major, don't take EE 126 after Stat 140. Stat 150 will cover the stochastic process stuff that EE 126 covers, but in more depth and detail. EE 126 straddles this weird spot between 140 and 150 because CS 70 is only half a semester of probability so 126 has to spend time covering some extra stuff that 70 doesn't do like MLE and MAP.

Don't delay EE 16B to your last semester of undergrad. That's a classic mistake that comes from a misconception of what the class is about. 16B isn't really EE. When people hear "electrical engineering," they think of circuits and amplifiers, but in reality, that class is about modern linear algebra methods in engineering and goes much beyond the level of Math 54 in terms of topics covered. I would consider it to be core if you want to do anything related to reinforcement learning and control.

Thanks! To follow up:

1. If STAT 140 overlaps significantly with CS 70, then why would STAT 140 have a larger workload than CS 70? I want to learn more about probability in STAT 140 so that I'm more prepared for EE 126 and I'm a stats major as well.

2. I plan to delay EE 16B to my last semester in undergrad.

I wasn't telling OP that stat 140 is entirely review, I was just telling them that EE 126 is designed to be a natural follow up to CS 70, while Stat 140 is designed to basically be a first introductory probability class. Why waste time relearning things when you can hit the ground running? If OP needs 140 as a stat major, EE 126 is too much overlap since it's not a full stochastic process course, and at that point, they should be taking Stat 150 (which IS a full stochastic course).

Data 100 isn't going to be necessary if you plan on taking 126, 127, 182, and 189. By the end of it all, you'll have built enough experience that learning the tools isn't really a problem. And since these classes will teach you the tools along the way, I don't think a separate tool class is necessary.

I dont necessarily agree with everything anon comp said. 

Stat140 goes much more indepth into probability than cs70, even though 70 has a fair amount of depth as well. Stat140 is partially advertised as prep for courses like data102 and CS189 (the textbook is great). 126 introduces probability more theoretically and then goes into more interesting engineering and ML applications, and is overall the more difficult but imo rewarding) course over 140 because you have a deeper understanding. Its a killer course though, but its significance is more far reaching than ML. So do a little more research on those courses and pick which one you want to take depending on your focus (a sizable chunk of people even take 140 as prep for 126 because 126 is so grindy, I didnt though, and im doing alright as an average student). A final word on these courses, if you really like 126 and probability, there is a whole world of courses that rely on probability that are more than ML and the like. Lots of stochastic signal processing courses, systems theory, robotics applications, etc... So I think a probability course and 16b (which I dont really like as a class tbh) unlock lots of cool courses as well. 

Data100 is (imo) an interesting medium workload course that has interesting projects and teaches you basically everything you need to do meaningful data science on your own at an amateur level. Its a cool class, even if its not really important to take, I think the main positive is that they teach you how to use real world tools instead of just theory. Also gives you a gentle exposure to basic topics you might go more indepth on in a class like 16b, 127 or 189. I think its a really great class for a first upper div in CS (kind of like 188). Although one negative ive seen is that there can be variance depending on the teachers, however the course staff is excellent (Suraj is a great head TA). 

I completely agree with comp that your second semester is sooo much more work than the first, and the first is definitely a lot of work, more than I would ever consider in a semester. Dont overbear yourself too early if your not in a rush, summer classes are available if you have time, and keeping stress low is (imo) one of the keys to doing well. Good luck mate.

You are correct. In fact, after CS 70, you should be able to jump into most stats classes that require 134 as a prereq such as 135 or 150 with little trouble, though you'll have a little catching up to do. If you're gonna take the full CS ML sequence, Data 100 isn't really worth taking.

The overlap comes from what I mentioned before, how 70+126 is more than 134 or 140, but less than 134/140+150. The areas of interest of the two departments overlap for their probability sequences, as well as machine learning (both departments run their own ML class). Most of the other statistics upperdivs are not covered in any CS classes and would be interesting standalone classes to take (ie time series or game theory).

<md>Sorry for the dumb question (I'm a freshman), but I am getting confused about why someone with similar interests to the OP who is already taking CS classes would major in statistics. I am getting the impression that
* DATA 100 (which is required for statistics if you don't do 133) doesn't teach you anything that you won't learn in more rigorous CS classes
* STAT 140 (which is also required for statistics if you don't do 134) is actually less rigorous than 70 + 126

Is there other overlap beyond this? And if so, are CS (non-statistics) majors able to get a similar depth of theoretical understanding to stats majors by skipping the courses that overlap and still taking a couple of 150-series stats courses?</md>

history.content:
As an incoming freshman, I'm taking CS 61A + MATH 54 + DATA 8 + CS 70 + Breadth(NUS 10) this semester.

For my second semester, I plan to take CS 61B + MATH 113 + DATA 100 + STAT 140 + Breadth(BIOENG 100). Could anyone help me to compare these two sets of workload?

Just wondering: how does the workload of 61B as compared with 61A? There are significantly more As in 61B than 61A, and 61A exams are really hard.

Thank you so much! I know how to choose then!
history.subject: CS 61A VS CS 61B
